title.narrative: Yes I Do Kenya

description.narrative: Deep-rooted norms and expectations of girls and boys makes families and communities feel the need to control the sexuality of girls by marrying them off and forcing them to undergo FGM/C. Gender inequality is putting girls in a subordinate position with regard to boys and men in (sexual) relationships. For example, girls cannot refuse to have unprotected sex and this is resulting in a high level of teenage pregnancies. Girls and boys lack a voice, as well as the support to break through these norms and practices. The means and structures available for adolescents to organise themselves are limited and they have little access to adolescent-friendly and good quality SRH information and services. There are close links between EM, FGM/C and teenage pregnancies and girls’ lack of education. Indeed, girls’ access to education is very restricted, which makes it difficult for them to find jobs later. It also hampers their economic independence. Legislation to outlaw FGM/C is either inadequate or is being poorly implemented.

During the inception phase a country-specific plan has been developed based on the overall intervention strategies and target groups and final beneficiaries have been identified. These will be represented here in the near future.

EM, FGM/C and teenage pregnancies have similar root causes and these practices mutually reinforce one another. Social and gender norms are deeply embedded in communities and this situation can only be changed if community leaders and most of the people, including boys and men, support the change. Key persons in the communities, including boys and men, will be turned into allies in the process of changing these norms, thereby helping to address the problem of EM, FGM/C and teenage pregnancies. A general lack of information about SRH and poor quality and access to the relevant services are perpetuating the above-mentioned problems. Adolescent boys and girls are being informed about SRH and given a voice to claim this information and these services. Girls are being given more control over their lives. This is being achieved by changing these norms and people’s behaviour, strengthening networks and structures for social mobilisation and embedding these in communities, and by involving the government and the private sector in improving SRH and services. All these will help to reduce EM, FGM/C and teenage pregnancies.
Final beneficiaries are girls between the age of 12 – 24 years, married and unmarried.

SUMMARY Millions of adolescent girls all over the world are facing a limited future because of early marriage (EM), teenage pregnancies and female genital mutilation/cutting (FGM/C). With this project, by changing the attitude of community members and other key persons and informing adolescent girls and boys, adolescents will be empowered to stand up for their sexual reproductive health and rights (SRHR). Through education and economic empowerment, supported by the relevant legislation and policies, the project will give adolescents alternatives beyond EM, teenage pregnancies and FGM/C. The project will be implemented between 2016 and 2020 by Plan International Nederland, together with partners Amref, Rutgers, Choice, KIT and the Netherlands Embassy in Addis Ababa and will be carried out in Ethiopia, Zambia, Malawi, Mozambique, Indonesia and Pakistan as well.
These will be represented here in the near future.

This programme is a follow up of the Plan regional EM programme (18+) in Malawi, Zambia and Mozambique, in which adolescents are being trained as agents of change to make their voice heard in claiming their SRH. The programme is being implemented by the Yes I Do alliance in which each partner is adding value by implementing part of one or more of the intervention strategies. Kenya was selected based upon on-going programmes of the alliance partners on FGM/C, EM and teenage pregnancies in the respective countries.

title.narrative: % girls aged 15-18 currently attending secondary school (Ilodokilani & Ewanso Kedong) (pathway 4)

description.narrative: A community-based cluster sample survey was administered at the household level among young girls and boys aged 15-24 in two intervention areas (Ilodokilani & Ewanso Kedong). The survey included question about child marriage. We obtained a sample size of 1400 using a standard formula- taking into account possible “design effects” because of the clustered sampling- we multiplied the required sample by 1.5 and had a ratio of 75% female respondents and 25% male respondents. A total of 1728 questionnaires were administered- which was above to the planned target. No contributing partners.

comment.narrative: % girls aged 15-18 currently attending secondary school (Ilodokilani & Ewanso Kedong) (pathway 4)

title.narrative: Service providers are capable to deliver services that are sensitive to rights of children and youth and gender equality (C2)
(qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in girls indicating safety in and out of school is a problem

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews with girls aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years and focus group discussions with groups of girls aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years.

comment.narrative: (qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in girls indicating safety in and out of school is a problem

At baseline safety out-of-school was an issue, because of the long distance from school to the homes and some girls when returning from school. At midline most girls reported that their school environment was safe and walking distance was a lot shorter in this community. There were no animals that could threaten their safety and crime rates were also low. Some respondents indicated that they feel safe at school and that they were not sexually harassed. Some boys entered a boarding school for girls, but were caught in time. At midline we heard less about rape as compared to the qualitative baseline. Although a gang rape case was mentioned and practices of communal virginity breaking exist. Ignorance was high among the four boys who raped a girl . At midline it was reported that some teachers sexually engage with girls, so in that sense security is affected. These teachers are often young, like 18 years –old who have finished high school and have to teach because there are not enough qualified government teachers available.

title.narrative: Children, youth or adults decide about their own future
(qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in perceived autonomy of girls between 15 - 24 years old

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews with girls aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years and focus group discussions with groups of girls aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years.

comment.narrative: (qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in perceived autonomy of girls between 15 - 24 years old

Most of the girls at primary school level reported that they couldn’t make their own decisions. It is the parents who decide upon FGM/C and child marriage. Most girls can’t resist the decisions made by their parents. Girls who are in post-primary school are less restricted and can decide more on their own. Some post-primary school level are guided whom to marry, but some girls can decide for themselves who to marry. Other observations are that some girls run to a rescue centre or see a teacher or chief to report that they have to go through FGM/C or forced marriage, and ask for help. Some rescue centres also provide scholarships to girls to receive financial assistance.

description.narrative: Training in financial literacy for boys in school

comment.narrative: Number of children, youth or adults who participated in skills trainings
Boys trained in Financial literracy

Training on financial literacy for boys in school. For this training role models from the community took time to talk to them sharing their life experiences and integrating FGM, CM, TP and other issues that hinder them from achieving their dreams.
